fr.lipn.uima.util.align
Class AnnotatedTextReader

java.lang.Object
  fr.lipn.uima.util.align.AnnotatedTextReader
Direct Known Subclasses:
SimpleTaggedTextReader, SimpleTokenByLineReader, TaggedTextFileReader
public abstract class AnnotatedTextReader
extends java.lang.Object

Main class in the package. Reads the annotated text and sends data to be processed to the other classes.
This package is meant to align two forms of a given text, one being the "original" (called the reference text) and the other one being a transformed version, generally by adding annotations (called the annotated text). The package is intended to provide flexibility about the kind of data processed and the way it is processed. For example it is possible to re-use the same componant for reading annotated text when one wants to produce different forms of output.
General principle: AnnotatedTextReader is an abstract class which has one implemented method, namely align(InputReader, AlignerConsumer). This method calls the three classes initialization methods, then processes the annotated text by calling processNextToken(InputReader, AlignerConsumer) for each token found, and finally calls the three classes closing methods.

  • processNextToken has to send data read from the annotated text to the InputReader;
  • The InputReader's method InputReader.receiveTokenAndAnnotation(AlignerConsumer, String, String) has to compare the data to the reference data, possibly doing some aligning stuff, and then send that new data to the AlignerConsumer;
  • Finally the AlignerConsumer's method AlignerConsumer.receiveTokenAndAnnotation(String, String, String, String, long, long) has to take this information and process it, for example by writing it to a file.

Author:
moreau

Constructor Detail

AnnotatedTextReader

public AnnotatedTextReader()
Method Detail

align

public void align(InputReader inputReader,
                  AlignerConsumer alignerConsumer)
           throws AlignmentException
Main alignment process. Parses the annotated text and the input text at the same time, token by token. For each token found in the annotated text, the method processNextToken(InputReader, AlignerConsumer) is called and is in charge to call InputReader.receiveTokenAndAnnotation(AlignerConsumer, String, String), which is itself in charge to call AlignerConsumer.receiveTokenAndAnnotation(String, String, String, String, long, long).
It may be noticed that the AlignerConsumer is initialized before the InputConsumer, which is itself initialized before the AnnotatedTextReader: this way the InputReader is allowed to start sending data to the AlignerConsumer in its init method, and same holds between the AnnotatedTextReader and the InputReader. The closing methods are called in in the reverse order, for the same reason.
There should no reason to override this method in normal use.

Parameters:
inputReader - The reader for the input text, used as a reference.
alignerConsumer - The alignment consumer, to which results are sent.
Throws:
AlignmentException

initReader

public abstract void initReader(InputReader inputReader,
                                AlignerConsumer alignerConsumer)
                         throws AlignmentException
Called before starting aligning process. Initialize any resource here. Notice that the InputReader has (normally) already been initialized before this method is called.

Throws:
AlignmentException

closeReader

public abstract void closeReader(InputReader inputReader,
                                 AlignerConsumer alignerConsumer)
                          throws AlignmentException
Called after finishing aligning process. Dispose any resource here. Notice that the InputReader has not (normally) been closed yet when this method is called.

Throws:
AlignmentException

hasToken

public abstract boolean hasToken()
Returns:
true while the annotated text is not totally read, false otherwise.

processNextToken

public abstract void processNextToken(InputReader inputReader,
                                      AlignerConsumer alignerConsumer)
                               throws AlignmentException
Parses the next token and possibly transmits data (token and/or annotation) to the InputReader. Should call InputReader.receiveTokenAndAnnotation(AlignerConsumer, String, String) to transmit data (if necessary). It is up to the actual reader to define how metadata is returned (e.g. before or after the token, or even without any token).

Throws:
AlignmentException

nextPosNonWhitespace

public static int nextPosNonWhitespace(java.lang.String s,
                                       int start)
Finds the next non-whitespace character in a string.

Parameters:
s - input string
start - start index
Returns:
first index after start corresponding to a non-whitespace character, or length of string if no such index found.
